overview: From 2025-10-01 to 2025-11-01, elizaos/eliza had 49 new PRs (45 merged), 17 new issues, and 25 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Imports not found in index.ts with Eliza CLI 1.61
topIssues.author: matteo-brandolino
topIssues.body:
## Describe the bug
When creating a new project using `elizaos create`, some imports in `index.ts` fail:
Module '"@Elizaos/core"' has no exported member 'logger'.ts(2305) Module '"@Elizaos/core"' has no exported member 'IAgentRuntime'.ts(2305) Module '"@Elizaos/core"' has no exported member 'ProjectAgent'.ts(2305)
Copy code

## To Reproduce
1. Install Eliza CLI 1.61.  
2. Run `elizaos create` to generate a new project.  
3. Open `index.ts` and try to import `logger`, `IAgentRuntime`, or `ProjectAgent` from `@Elizaos/core`.  

## Expected behavior
These members should be correctly exported and importable from `@Elizaos/core` in a newly generated project.  

## Screenshots
<!-- Add screenshots if applicable -->

## Additional context
- Eliza CLI version: 1.61  
- This occurs immediately after project creation without any modifications.  
- Possible regression from previous versions of `@Elizaos/core`.

topIssues.title: The documentation for plugins isn't correct.
topIssues.author: ryanmstokes
topIssues.body: Seriously how are you even letting anyone use this right now? This is one of the worst documented frameworks I've ever seen despite having so much documentation. You can't even scaffold a plugin following your documentation without it throwing errors.

topIssues.title: `Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code'` after installing elizaOS CLI
topIssues.author: schmidsi
topIssues.body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm following the steps described here: https://docs.elizaos.ai/installation#cli-version-conflicts-mismatches

After running `elizaos --version`, I get an error message: `error: Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code' from '/Users/schmidsi/.bun/install/global/node_modules/@elizaos/cli/dist/index.js'`

**To Reproduce**

1. Install the CLI globally: `bun install -g @elizaos/cli`
2. Verify installation: `elizaos --version`
3. Observe the error: `error: Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code' from '/Users/schmidsi/.bun/install/global/node_modules/@elizaos/cli/dist/index.js'`

**Expected behavior**

The `elizaos --version` command should display the installed version number (e.g., `1.6.2`).

**Screenshots**
```
$ bun install -g @elizaos/cli
bun add v1.2.15 (df017990)
Saved lockfile

installed @elizaos/cli@1.6.2 with binaries:

elizaos

[53.00ms] done

$ elizaos --version
error: Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code' from '/Users/schmidsi/.bun/install/global/node_modules/@elizaos/cli/dist/index.js'

Bun v1.2.15 (macOS arm64)
```

**Additional context**

- OS: macOS 15.6.1 (Build 24G90)
- Node version: v24.1.0
- Bun version: v1.3.1
- The `@anthropic-ai/claude-code` dependency appears to be missing from the package's transitive dependencies

topPRs.title: chore: merge develop into main
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
Merging latest changes from develop branch into main

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Introduces a pluggable message service and generateText API in core, unifies server startup/config, adds a Docker/ECS deploy command to the CLI, enables duplicate agent names via UUID-only identity, and improves memory pagination, plugin/character handling, and tests.
> 
> - **Core**:
>   - Adds pluggable `IMessageService` with `DefaultMessageService` and `shouldRespond` logic; centralizes message deletion/channel clear.
>   - Introduces `generateText()` API and refines model types/options.
>   - Adds character utilities (`buildCharacterPlugins`, parsing/validation/merge) and secrets/env loading helpers.
>   - Enhances DB `getMemories` with `offset` pagination.
>   - Extensive tests for runtime, prompts, UUID, character, message service.
> - **Server**:
>   - Unifies startup via `AgentServer.start(config)` (auto-init, port resolution, optional agents), removes plugin/config managers.
>   - Loader now ensures deterministic UUID from name; improves character env secret merging.
>   - Agent update endpoint restarts on plugin changes, in-place updates otherwise.
>   - Memory routes map `channelId`→agent `roomId`.
>   - Broad test updates (bootstrap autoload, CLI API, lifecycle, socket flow, CRUD UUID).
> - **CLI**:
>   - Adds `deploy` command (Docker build/push to AWS ECR, ECS deploy) with API/Docker utilities.
>   - Adds `tee eigen` wrapper; refactors `start/dev/test` to new server API; improves `create` flags and template resolution.
>   - Removes legacy module/port utilities; updates docs and dependencies.
> - **Plugins**:
>   - Bootstrap: routes message handling through runtime message service; removes legacy provider; improves embedding checks.
>   - SQL: drops unique constraint on agent name (UUID-only identity) and adds migration/tests; supports `offset` in memories.
> - **Client/Examples**:
>   - Adjusts entityId mapping for memories; adds `examples/generate-text.ts`.
> - **Misc**:
>   - Bumps versions to `1.6.2-alpha.26`; updates Renovate config and disables tests for types-only pkg.
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 0538c6551724caf8ad746d613ee5adaa06407d48. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

topPRs.title: feat: create @elizaos/react package with headless React hooks
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
## Overview This PR introduces a new **** package containing headless, reusable React hooks extracted from the client package. This enables external developers to build custom UIs for ElizaOS agents while maintaining full type safety and React Query integration. ## What's New ### Package: A standalone package providing headless React hooks with: - ✅ Zero UI coupling (no toasts, navigation, or DOM dependencies) - ✅ Full TypeScript support with proper type declarations - ✅ TanStack React Query for caching and state management - ✅ Network-aware polling that adapts to connection quality - ✅ Composable lifecycle callbacks (onSuccess, onError, onMutate) ### Hooks Included (30 total) **Agents (8 hooks)** - `useAgents`, `useAgent`, `useStartAgent`, `useStopAgent` - `useAgentActions`, `useDeleteLog`, `useAgentPanels`, `useAgentsWithDetails` **Runs (2 hooks)** - `useAgentRuns`, `useAgentRunDetail` **Messaging (5 hooks)** - `useServers`, `useChannels`, `useChannelDetails`, `useChannelParticipants`, `useDeleteChannel` **Messages (3 hooks)** - `useChannelMessages` (stateful with pagination), `useDeleteChannelMessage`, `useClearChannelMessages` **Memories (6 hooks)** - `useAgentMemories`, `useDeleteMemory`, `useDeleteAllMemories`, `useUpdateMemory`, `useDeleteGroupMemory`, `useClearGroupChat` **Internal/Agent-Perspective (6 hooks)** - `useAgentInternalActions`, `useDeleteAgentInternalLog`, `useAgentInternalMemories` - `useDeleteAgentInternalMemory`, `useDeleteAllAgentInternalMemories`, `useUpdateAgentInternalMemory` ## Architecture ```tsx import { QueryClient, QueryClientProvider } from '@tanstack/react-query'; import { ElizaReactProvider, useAgents, useStartAgent } from '@elizaos/react'; const queryClient = new QueryClient(); function App() { return ( ); } function AgentList() { const { data: agents, isLoading } = useAgents(); const startAgent = useStartAgent({ onSuccess: () => toast.success('Agent started!'), }); if (isLoading) return
Loading...
; return (
{agents?.map((agent) => (

{agent.name}

))}
); } ``` ## Benefits 1. **Reusability**: External developers can build custom UIs using these hooks 2. **Type Safety**: Full TypeScript support with types from `@elizaos/api-client` 3. **Performance**: Smart polling adapts to network quality (2G → 4G) 4. **Separation of Concerns**: UI logic stays in components, data logic in hooks 5. **Future-proof**: Ready for migration of `packages/client` to consume these hooks ## Testing - ✅ Package builds successfully with TypeScript declarations - ✅ All hooks properly typed with React Query v5 signatures - ✅ Zero build errors or type issues - ✅ Ready for integration into turbo build pipeline ## Next Steps (Future PRs) - Migrate `packages/client` to consume `@elizaos/react` - Add unit tests for hooks with mocked ElizaClient - Publish to npm for external consumption ## Files Changed - `packages/react/` - New package with provider, hooks, and documentation - Comprehensive README with installation, API reference, and examples --- **Ready for review!** 🚀 --- > [!NOTE] > Introduces a new `@elizaos/react` package with headless, type-safe React hooks and provider (plus build/docs), integrates it into the workspace, and publishes comprehensive core type declarations. > > - **New package `@elizaos/react`**: > - Headless React hooks and provider (`ElizaReactProvider`) built on `@tanstack/react-query` and `@elizaos/api-client`. > - Hooks for: agents, runs, messaging (servers/channels), messages (stateful + pagination), memories, and internal agent-perspective operations. > - Network-aware polling, composable mutation callbacks, TypeScript types, and index exports. > - Build tooling (`build.ts`, bunfig, tsconfigs), and comprehensive README. > - **Workspace integration**: > - Added to lockfile/workspace with peer/dev deps. > - **Type declarations**: > - Added/updated numerous `@elizaos/core` `.d.ts` and source maps to expose APIs/types for consumers. > > Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 5a290e0071637d785858567d960ab7d1d5e54456. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).

topPRs.title: feat(core): add MessageService interface and default implementation
topPRs.author: 0xbbjoker

topPRs.title: elizaos deploy r2 artifacts style
topPRs.author: ChristopherTrimboli
topPRs.body:
## Overview

This PR completely migrates the ElizaOS CLI deployment system from traditional Docker image builds to a modern bootstrapper architecture. This change significantly improves deployment speed, reduces resource usage, and eliminates platform size limitations.

## What Changed

### 🚀 New Bootstrapper Architecture

**Added:**
- `deploy-bootstrapper.ts` - Core bootstrapper deployment logic
- `artifact.ts` - Artifact creation and management utilities
- `r2-client.ts` - R2 storage client for future direct operations
- Bootstrapper Dockerfile template and entrypoint script
- Support for deterministic artifact creation with `.gitignore` respect

**Key Features:**
- Creates lightweight tar.gz artifacts (typically <50MB vs 500MB+ Docker images)
- Uploads artifacts to Cloudflare R2 via secure API
- Uses minimal shared bootstrapper image (~100MB)
- Fetches project code at container startup
- Supports both Bun and npm lockfiles
- Implements SHA256 checksum verification

### 🗑️ Removed Legacy Docker Code

**Deleted:**
- `utils/docker.ts` - All Docker build/export utilities (~280 lines)
- `deployWithDocker()` function (~300 lines)
- Docker-specific CLI options (`--use-docker`, `--tag`, `--no-build`)
- Dockerfile generation and management code

### 📦 Dependencies

**Added:**
- `tar` - For creating compressed archives
- `ignore` - For respecting .gitignore rules
- `node-fetch` - For HTTP operations
- `form-data` - For multipart uploads

## Why This Change?

### Problems with Old Approach:
- **Size Limits**: Docker images often exceeded 500MB-2GB, hitting platform limits
- **Slow Uploads**: Uploading entire Docker images was bandwidth-intensive
- **Version Conflicts**: Single Docker image could break older projects
- **Resource Waste**: Duplicated base layers for every deployment

### Benefits of Bootstrapper:
- **10x Smaller Uploads**: Only project code, not entire OS/runtime
- **Faster Deployments**: 30-60s vs 5-10 minutes
- **Version Isolation**: Each project maintains its own dependencies
- **Better Caching**: Shared base image, project-specific dependencies
- **Platform Friendly**: Works within Cloudflare's 50GB limits

## Technical Implementation

### Deployment Flow:
1. **Artifact Creation**
   ```typescript
   // Creates deterministic tar.gz with project files
   const artifact = await createArtifact({
     projectPath: cwd,
     outputPath: artifactPath,
     excludePatterns: ['.git', 'node_modules', '.env'],
     deterministic: true
   });
   ```

2. **Upload to R2**
   ```typescript
   // Uploads via Cloud API with checksum verification
   const uploadResponse = await apiClient.uploadArtifact({
     projectId: projectName,
     version: projectVersion,
     checksum: artifactChecksum,
     size: artifactSize,
     artifactPath
   });
   ```

3. **Container Deployment**
   ```typescript
   // Deploys bootstrapper with artifact URL
   const containerConfig = {
     image_tag: "elizaos/bootstrapper:latest",
     environment_vars: {
       R2_ARTIFACT_URL: artifactData.artifactUrl,
       R2_TOKEN: artifactData.token,
       R2_ARTIFACT_CHECKSUM: artifactChecksum,
       START_CMD: "bun run start"
     }
   };
   ```

### Bootstrapper Runtime:
- Alpine Linux base with Bun pre-installed
- Downloads artifact using one-time scoped token
- Verifies SHA256 checksum
- Extracts project files
- Installs dependencies from lockfile
- Executes START_CMD

## Breaking Changes

⚠️ **Removed CLI Options:**
- `--use-docker` - No longer supported
- `--tag` - Not applicable to bootstrapper
- `--no-build` - Build happens in container
- `--dockerfile` - Bootstrapper uses standard image

**Migration Guide:**
```bash
# Old (no longer works)
elizaos deploy --use-docker --tag my-image:v1

# New (default behavior)
elizaos deploy

# With existing artifact
elizaos deploy --skip-artifact --artifact-path ./dist/artifact.tar.gz
```

## Testing

### Manual Testing:
- ✅ Deployed sample project with bootstrapper
- ✅ Verified artifact creation and upload
- ✅ Confirmed container starts and runs correctly
- ✅ Tested with both Bun and npm projects
- ✅ Validated checksum verification
- ✅ Tested artifact cleanup (keeps last 3)

### Performance Comparison:
| Metric | Docker Mode | Bootstrapper |
|--------|------------|--------------|
| Artifact Size | 500MB-2GB | 10-50MB |
| Upload Time | 2-10 min | 10-30 sec |
| Total Deploy Time | 5-15 min | 1-2 min |
| Storage Used | 2GB/deploy | 50MB/deploy |

   // Uploads via Cloud API with checksum verification
   const uploadResponse = await apiClient.uploadArtifact({
     projectId: projectName,
     version: projectVersion,
     checksum: artifactChecksum,
     size: artifactSize,
     artifactPath
   });nged

### 🚀 New Artifact Management System

**Added Endpoints:**
- `POST /api/v1/artifacts/upload` - Request presigned URL and upload artifacts
- `GET /api/v1/artifacts` - List project artifacts

**Database Changes:**
- New `artifacts` table with organization/project/version tracking
- Unique constraint on version per project
- Indexes for efficient querying

**Key Features:**
- Presigned S3 URLs for direct R2 uploads
- SHA256 checksum verification
- 10MB artifact size limit (configurable)
- Artifact metadata storage (Eliza version, Node version, etc.)
- One-time scoped token generation for secure retrieval

### 🔄 Container Route Updates

**Modified:**
- Added bootstrapper fields to container schema
- Default to bootstrapper mode (`use_bootstrapper: true`)
- Store artifact metadata in container record
- Pass bootstrapper config to Cloudflare deployment

**Schema Changes:**
```typescript
const createContainerSchema = z.object({
  name: z.string(),
  port: z.number(),
  environment_vars: z.record(z.string()),
  
  // New bootstrapper fields
  use_bootstrapper: z.boolean().default(true),
  artifact_url: z.string().optional(),
  artifact_checksum: z.string().optional(),
  image_tag: z.string().default("elizaos/bootstrapper:latest")
});
```

### 🗑️ Deprecated Legacy Endpoints

**Marked as Deprecated:**
- `POST /api/v1/containers/upload-image` - Docker image upload
- `CloudflareService.uploadImage()` - Docker upload method

These remain functional with deprecation warnings for backward compatibility.

## Technical Implementation

### Artifact Upload Flow:

1. **Request Upload URL**
   ```typescript
   // Client requests presigned URL
   POST /api/v1/artifacts/upload
   {
     projectId: "my-project",
     version: "1.0.0",
     checksum: "sha256...",
     size: 1048576
   }
   ```

2. **Generate Presigned URL**
   ```typescript
   // Server creates S3 presigned URL for R2
   const putCommand = new PutObjectCommand({
     Bucket: process.env.R2_BUCKET_NAME,
     Key: `artifacts/${org}/${project}/${version}/${id}.tar.gz`,
     ContentType: 'application/gzip',
     ContentLength: size,
     ChecksumSHA256: checksum
   });
   
   const uploadUrl = await getSignedUrl(r2Client, putCommand, {
     expiresIn: 600 // 10 minutes
   });
   ```

3. **Store Metadata**
   ```typescript
   // Save artifact record
   await db.insert(artifacts).values({
     id: artifactId,
     organization_id: user.organization_id,
     project_id: projectId,
     version,
     checksum,
     size,
     r2_key,
     r2_url: publicUrl,
     metadata,
     created_by: user.id
   });
   ```

### Container Deployment:

```typescript
// Deploy with bootstrapper configuration
const deployment = await cloudflare.deployContainer({
  name: config.name,
  imageTag: "elizaos/bootstrapper:latest",
  port: config.port,
  environmentVars: {
    ...config.environment_vars,
    R2_ARTIFACT_URL: config.artifact_url,
    R2_TOKEN: generatedToken,
    R2_ARTIFACT_CHECKSUM: config.artifact_checksum
  }
});
```

## Database Migration

```sql
-- 0006_add_artifacts_table.sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS artifacts (
  id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  organization_id TEXT NOT NULL,
  project_id TEXT NOT NULL,
  version TEXT NOT NULL,
  checksum TEXT NOT NULL,
  size INTEGER NOT NULL,
  r2_key TEXT NOT NULL,
  r2_url TEXT NOT NULL,
  metadata JSONB DEFAULT '{}',
  created_by TEXT NOT NULL,
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NOW() NOT NULL
);

CREATE INDEX idx_artifacts_org_project ON artifacts(organization_id, project_id);
CREATE INDEX idx_artifacts_project_version ON artifacts(project_id, version);
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX uniq_artifact_version ON artifacts(organization_id, project_id, version);
```

## Environment Variables

**New Required Variables:**
```bash
# R2 Storage Configuration
R2_ACCOUNT_ID=your_cloudflare_account_id
R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID=your_r2_access_key
R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=your_r2_secret_key
R2_BUCKET_NAME=elizaos-artifacts
R2_PUBLIC_DOMAIN=artifacts.elizacloud.ai  # Optional custom domain
```

## Security Considerations

- ✅ Presigned URLs expire after 10 minutes
- ✅ One-time tokens for artifact retrieval
- ✅ SHA256 checksum verification on upload and download
- ✅ Organization-scoped artifact isolation
- ✅ Size limits to prevent abuse (10MB default)

## Performance Impact

### Metrics:
| Operation | Old (Docker) | New (Bootstrapper) |
|-----------|-------------|-------------------|
| Upload Size | 500MB-2GB | 10-50MB |
| API Processing | 30-60s | <1s |
| Storage Cost | High | 95% reduction |
| Network Usage | High | 90% reduction |

### Load Testing:
- Handled 100 concurrent artifact uploads
- Average upload time: 5 seconds
- No performance degradation observed

## Breaking Changes

⚠️ **Default Behavior Change:**
- Containers now default to bootstrapper mode
- `use_bootstrapper` defaults to `true` instead of `false`

**Backward Compatibility:**
- Legacy Docker endpoints remain functional with warnings
- Existing containers continue to work
- Gradual migration path available

## Testing

- ✅ Artifact upload with checksum validation
- ✅ Presigned URL generation and expiry
- ✅ Container deployment with bootstrapper
- ✅ Legacy endpoint deprecation warnings
- ✅ Database migration rollback tested
- ✅ R2 connectivity and error handling

topPRs.title: feat: migrate to UUID-only agent identification
topPRs.author: 0xbbjoker
topPRs.body:
<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
> [!NOTE]
> Agents now use randomly generated UUIDs (not names) for identity; duplicate names are allowed, with loader/runtime/server/DB updated plus migrations and tests.
> 
> - **Core/runtime (`packages/core`)**:
>   - Generate `agentId` via `uuidv4()` (no name-derived IDs).
>   - `ensureAgentExists` now requires `agent.id`, updates/creates strictly by UUID.
>   - Logs/messages reference `agent.id`.
> - **Server (`packages/server`)**:
>   - Loader `jsonToCharacter` assigns `id` if missing and supports env prefixes by `name` and `id`.
>   - Agent CRUD create path uses provided `character.id` (no name-to-UUID), and updates active runtimes in-place.
>   - Added tests for loader UUID generation and CRUD behavior with duplicate names.
> - **SQL Plugin (`packages/plugin-sql`)**:
>   - Schema: drop unique constraint on `agents.name`.
>   - `createAgent` checks duplicate `id` only; allows duplicate `name`.
>   - Integration and migration tests verifying duplicate-name support, UUID-based CRUD, and constraint removal.
> - **CLI (`packages/cli`)**:
>   - Scenario factory assigns random `id` to test character (no name-based ID).
> - **Project starter**:
>   - Character docs note auto-generated `id` and option to set a fixed UUID.
> - **Tests**:
>   - Extensive suites across core/server/sql to ensure UUID independence from names and proper migrations.
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 93f269089b99832050651406cf7047f4a9392463. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- New Features
  - Agents/characters now use randomly generated UUIDs for identity; multiple agents can share the same name.
  - Loader auto-assigns an ID when missing; explicit IDs are preserved.
  - Environment variable prefixing now derives from the agent ID for consistent configuration.
- Documentation
  - Starter character docs updated to explain ID generation and how to set a fixed ID.
- Chores
  - Database schema updated to remove the unique constraint on agent names, enabling duplicate names while keeping ID-based operations.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

completedItems.title: fix(service-interfaces): skip test execution for types-only package
completedItems.body:
The @elizaos/service-interfaces package contains only TypeScript interface
definitions and has no runtime logic or tests. The test script was failing

topContributors.summary: standujar: Focused on significant refactoring of core components, introducing a new `mentionContext` interface in `elizaos/eliza#6030` which simplified the codebase (+520/-681 lines) and improved response logic. This core change was then propagated to dependent plugins like in `elizaos-plugins/plugin-discord#19`. They also fixed a bug in `elizaos-plugins/plugin-openrouter#15` related to AI SDK v5 tool results extraction. Their activity shows a primary focus on refactoring, bug fixes, and widespread configuration updates.

0xbbjoker: This month, 0xbbjoker focused on enhancing plugin functionality and improving code maintainability within the `elizaos/eliza` repository. They delivered a key feature by adding an offset parameter for memory retrieval in the SQL plugin (elizaos/eliza#6032), a substantial change of +516/-209 lines. Additionally, they improved codebase health by removing 289 lines of unused code in a separate refactoring effort (elizaos/eliza#6029). Their work shows a dual focus on feature development and code quality, and they also supported the team through code review and comments.

wtfsayo: This month, wtfsayo focused on improving code health and repository maintenance, executing a significant code standardization and formatting refactor in elizaos/eliza#6027 (+1124/-1385 lines). They also removed obsolete development files in elizaos/eliza#6026 and expanded the plugin ecosystem by adding a new relay plugin to the registry in elizaos-plugins/registry#234. Their work shows a primary focus on bugfixes and other maintenance, touching mostly code and configuration files.
ChristopherTrimboli: No activity this month.

odilitime: This month, odilitime's contributions were focused on supporting the team through code review. They completed 3 reviews, approving 2 and requesting changes on 1, and left 3 comments on pull requests.

yungalgo: This month, yungalgo's work was centered on improving documentation quality. They contributed a bugfix that resolved broken plugin links in the plugin registry overview page (elizaos/docs#74). All of their contributions, which also included commenting on an issue, were focused on bugfixes within the documentation.

tcm390: Focused on bug fixes within the `elizaos/eliza` repository, merging two pull requests to improve stability. Their most significant contribution involved exposing the state cache and fixing bootstrap types in PR #6045. Overall, their work, which also included one code review approval, touched 53 files and was primarily categorized as bug fixes.

madjin: Focused on enhancing the functionality and deployment process of the `elizaos.github.io` repository this month. They delivered a key fix to enable dynamic stat copying for all tracked repositories (#157) and improved project accessibility by adding a new deployment guide for forks (#158). Madjin also proactively planned future work by opening several enhancement issues and began implementing adaptive rate limiting to optimize performance (#160). Their contributions were primarily centered on bug fixes and feature work, touching code, configuration, and documentation files.

0xRabbidfly: This month, 0xRabbidfly focused on identifying and reporting user experience issues across the plugin ecosystem. They reported an issue where sending an image also rendered the URI for the user, creating tickets in `elizaos-plugins/plugin-knowledge` (#43) and `elizaos-plugins/plugin-telegram` (#18).

tylermcwilliams: Focused on expanding core functionality by implementing the new `generateText()` API in `elizaos/eliza` via PR #6062. This was a significant feature contribution, adding over 2,600 lines of code and representing their primary deliverable for the month. In addition to this implementation, they engaged in technical discussions by commenting on four issues. Their work shows a clear focus on new feature development, supported by corresponding test work.

letmehateu: This month, letmehateu focused on documentation maintenance for the `elizaos/eliza` repository. Their primary contribution was fixing an old and broken link via PR #6047. All of their code changes were concentrated in documentation files.

5c0: Focused on a significant refactoring effort this month, opening a large pull request in elizaos/eliza (#6063). This single PR represents a substantial undertaking, modifying 111 files with over 5,500 new lines of code. Their activity shows a clear focus on code refactoring within the elizaos/eliza repository.

borisudovicic: Focused entirely on project planning and task definition within the elizaos/eliza repository this month. They created 30 issues to scope out a wide range of initiatives, including high-level efforts like "API Redesign" (#5917), "Modernization" (#5919), and "Developer Experience Enhancements" (#5931). This work also included defining new features such as a "Cloud API Plugin for Framework LLMs" (#6049), demonstrating a clear focus on shaping the project's future direction.

matteo-brandolino: This month, matteo-brandolino focused on identifying and reporting issues within the Eliza ecosystem. They opened a bug report concerning the Eliza CLI where imports were not being found (elizaos/eliza#6031) and contributed to discussions by commenting on two issues.
ryanmstokes: Focused on improving documentation quality this month by identifying and reporting an issue with incorrect plugin documentation in the elizaos/eliza repository (#6070).
douglasg14b: This month, douglasg14b contributed to improving project documentation by identifying and reporting an issue where all plugin links were broken (elizaos/eliza#6061).

n1n-api: This month's activity was focused on proposing a new integration within the elizaos/eliza repository. They opened issue #6064 to suggest adding the n1n.ai API as a model provider. There were no other contributions during this period.

kempsterrrr: This month, kempsterrrr's activity was focused on the elizaos/eliza repository, where they opened an issue to improve the developer setup by adding a .gitignore file during project creation (elizaos/eliza#6074).
TensorNull: This month, TensorNull's activity was limited to proposing a new feature by opening an issue in elizaos/eliza (#6055) to request CometAPI support.
FellowTraveler: No activity this month.
